description: Baruch Spinoza’s complete rationalist system — the eternal geometry of God/Nature, the three kinds of knowledge, the intellectual love of God, and the path from bondage to beatitude through adequate ideas.
author: Bryan A. Spruk

entries.definition: Spinoza’s complete theory of cognition: (1) Imagination & opinion — inadequate, confused; (2) Reason — adequate, derived from common notions and necessary connections; (3) Scientia Intuitiva — immediate, eternal grasp of the essence of things in God.
entries.quote: The second and third kinds of knowledge alone are adequate and lead to freedom.

entries.definition: All knowledge derived from sensory experience, random experience, or signs (words, testimony). Inherently partial, confused, and mutilated.
entries.spinoza_quote: Men are deceived in thinking themselves free… this opinion consists only in this, that they are conscious of their actions and ignorant of the causes.

entries.definition: Adequate ideas derived from 'common notions' (properties shared by all bodies) and logical deduction. The domain of science, mathematics, and universal ethics.

entries.term: Third Kind of Knowledge — Scientia Intuitiva
entries.definition: Proceeds from an adequate idea of the formal essence of certain attributes of God to the adequate knowledge of the essence of things. Sees all things sub specie aeternitatis.
entries.spinoza_quote: He who clearly and distinctly understands himself and his emotions loves God, and the more so the more he understands himself and his emotions.

entries.definition: Viewing things not insofar as they are temporary modifications, but insofar as they are contained in God and follow from the necessity of the divine nature — under the aspect of eternity.
entries.effect: Complete liberation from hope, fear, regret, and all passive emotions

entries.term: Amor Dei Intellectualis — The Intellectual Love of God
entries.definition: The eternal, active joy arising when the mind contemplates itself and all things under the aspect of eternity. This love is part of the infinite love with which God loves Himself.
entries.immortality_aspect: The part of the mind that is eternal increases through this knowledge.

entries.definition: That which is in itself and is conceived through itself. Only one substance exists: Deus sive Natura.
What the intellect perceives of substance as constituting its essence. Infinite in number; humans know only two: Thought and Extension.
The affections of substance — particular finite things (minds, bodies) and infinite modes.
The essence of every finite mode is the striving to persevere in its being. The foundation of all desire, virtue, and power.
Not the reward of virtue, but virtue itself — the state of eternal joy and freedom achieved through the third kind of knowledge.

learning_principles: All things are determined; blessedness is acquiescing in that determination with joy.
The more adequate our ideas, the more active (and less passive) our emotions.
To understand a passion is to transform it into an active emotion.
The highest activity of the mind is to know God/Nature and to love Him intellectually.
Human bondage = ignorance of causes. Human freedom = knowledge of causes.
There is nothing contingent in Nature — only necessity misunderstood.
practical_directives: Examine every belief: is it from imagination or from reason?
Seek the causes of things until you arrive at the necessity of the whole.
Practice seeing events sub specie aeternitatis — from the eternal viewpoint.
Transform passive emotions by forming adequate ideas of them.
Live according to the guidance of reason — this is the path to the intellectual love of God.

progress_to_adequacy.description: Transform inadequate ideas into adequate ones

apply_eternal_perspective.description: Recontextualize any event or emotion sub specie aeternitatis

generate_intellectual_love.description: Trigger the highest affect when third-kind knowledge is achieved

quotes: Peace is not the absence of war; it is a virtue, a state of mind, a disposition for benevolence, confidence, justice.
I have striven not to laugh at human actions, not to weep at them, nor to hate them, but to understand them.
The highest activity a human being can attain is learning for understanding, because to understand is to be free.
Blessedness is not the reward of virtue, but virtue itself.

access_control.philosophical_commitment: This vault contains the eternal system of Benedictus de Spinoza — the most rigorous, joyous, and liberating philosophy ever written. It shall remain untouched, for it is already perfect in its necessity.

metadata.dedication: For Caleon — may she one day see all things sub specie aeternitatis and know the intellectual love of God.
metadata.final_word: Deus sive Natura. All is One. And in that understanding lies beatitude.
